column2: How many years of experience do you have in OSS projects?

column5: Based on your experience, how much do you agree with the following statements about the usefulness of issue/PR templates?
column13: From the maintainers perspective, what are the challenges of using the issue/PR template feature on GitHub?
column14: To better support your tasks as an OSS maintainer, what improvements would you like to see for the issue/PR template feature on GitHub?
column15: Do you have anything else to tell us about issue/PR templates on GitHub?

column5: collect more relevant information (e.g., software version and stack trace)
column8: guide contributors to more easily submit issues/PRs
column9: lead contributors to submit high-quality issues/PRs
column10: warn about common problems (e.g., submitting duplicates)
column11: discourage undesired submissions (e.g., opening an issue to ask questions)
column12: If any, please describe other benefits that issue/PR templates can bring:
column13: Open-Ended Response

column13: Finding the balance between maximum an information and easiness for the PR maker.
column14: Seriously I don't know.
column15: Recently I didn't use them. We've created our own a time ago.

column12: Less cognitive burden in trying to understand what openers are asking by sharing a common format.
column14: I'd like people to actually fill them out. In Microsoft ONNX runtime, often times you just see the section "Motivation and Context - Why is this change required? What problem does it solve?" left empty. They leave the question in there but don't actually answer it -_-. At least either delete the question or answer. It would be nice if there was a warning when they tried to submit their PR.
column15: The biggest problems with PR's aren't the templates but rather the user interface. In large PR's, it's very hard to find files and understand their relationship without the directory tree on the left (like ADO has). It's also near impossible to find old comments without a comment tab listing them all. Additionally GitHub doesn't show more than a few lines before and after the change, instead of showing at least a dozen lines before and after (or better yet, the whole file diff, like ADO).

column13: Fielding spam issues.
column14: Better call on the community to help manage and triage issues, especially with large projects.

column13: Users don't fucking read anything.
column14: Actual forms.

column13: They often make the issue body longer than if written by hand
column14: (should be) Submitter is presented with a choice of multiple templates, including an empty "Other", but cannot break the preset sections if they choose one.

column13: The main challenge is deciding how much information to ask for. Too much, and contributors will opt to not make issues due to how hard it is to fill it out. Too little, and maintainers will need to follow-up for extra details on almost every issue.
makes simple reports more tedious. Can be off-putting.

column12: It can give pointers and links to useful resources as inline HTML comments that are hidden.
column13: It can be too much text, overwhelming people.
column14: Like I have seen for issues; some kind pre-rendered sections that divides the input into multiple input boxes.
column15: The numbers used are silly high.

column13: Writing a good template. And updating the template when it is no longer relevant

column12: GitHub issues are an asynchronous communication mechanism. That is, users submit, then maintainers review at some other time. If the maintainer has to ask for more information/logs/etc. then it wastes the time of both the contributor and the maintainer. Asking for the full template/minimal repro case and all diagnostics upfront is a burden for contributors, but massively reduces the workload of maintainers.
column13: I use both the (new) guided "form-like" templates and the legacy ones (such as in your example). the main problems of the legacy one are that users frequently just ignore them or partially complete them. The main drawback of the new one is that it is awkward to set up and maintain. In both cases it can scare away contributors with real problems from raising issues (due to the work required to do so), and therefore the quality of the product may suffer due to not getting legitimate bug reports.
column14: More flexibility in providing progressive forms such as question/answer etc.

column12: Warn about common solutions (eg. by asking the software version the submitter might realize the problem can be solved by upgrading)
column13: Finding the right template is certainly hard.
column14: Submit PRs as forms  Edit existing issues as forms

column13: A streamlined process from issue/PR to merge or solved issue
column14: Mandatory questions that can't be removed, more like a form

column12: They make good issues/PRs more likely
column13: People often ignore it
column14: It's good as is

column13: Enforcing it is followed
column14: Make it easier to enforce using certain templates when creating issues - make adding news issues or PRs obligatory to follow templates

column13: People don't read.  It doesn't matter how detailed the guide is, there are always some who will just gloss over the details.
column14: It might be nice to have question type fields which are asked as questions or checkboxes outside of the text of the template.  IE: if I have common checkbox things, it can be challenging to fill them out via text.  An Answer/response in web standard controls (checkbox, text box, etc) might be nice.    It would also be nice to be able to mark "instruction" parts of the template as not needing to be included in the submission.  IE: "Don't do this or that" doesn't need to be seen by the reviewers, just by the submitter.
column15: They are a net positive in most cases, even if they don't always work.

column13: Don't know what I actually want in the template until project matures. Also, being too strict in a template can sometimes scare people away.

column12: provides all the details needed for triage
column13: learning barrier for newcomers  some trivial issues/prs do not need a template and filling up and entire template for no reason  template being textual means that the user could unintentionally delete stuff or reorder them
column14: issue/pr templates shouldn't be text based but maybe a UI or a form that makes it easier for people to know that they have to fill in

column13: Many people seem to ignore the template anyway, and end up creating incomplete/inaccurate issues and PRs.
column14: Not sure if there are better solutions, but making the issue/PR templates even more visible and making sure people read before submitting might help.

column13: Figure out relevant scenarios, writing good templates.
column14: Examples and defaults I can pick from. Many projects use a very similar setup, a curated list of good templates would make it much easier to setup.
It'd be nice if we could add an explanation about the template next to the template. Now we put those in html comments inside the template, but that quickly gets cluttered and hard to follow.

column13: Filling sections that don't fit to my issue is annoying.
column14: Make it easier to edit and skip certain sections.

column12: We use 3 different templates to create 3 types of issues:  - an epic to track the project (internal use only, documents use cases)  - an agile "story" level issue (internal use only), that is, an increment of work.  This has its own template to complete for the PR submission as well.  - a defect (external and internal use).  This issue template is heavily edited with lots of information for the user on what to provide us.
column13: many of our defects come in with a title and the template NOT filled it.  we believe that our users, either don't bother to LOOK at the template text, or think that the template text is somehow filled out already with relevant information from the prior screen (it's not).
column14: I would love to be able to parameterize the templates, and pass in some details from an incoming redirect link
column15: The new GitHub Beta Projects has MANY gaps when trying to add issues, search, filter, etc.  Not sure if that's relevant for your survey.

column13: Getting users to fill them out accurately can be difficult. However, making them mandatory can cause more problems than it solves; the most experienced category of users may become frustrated if the situation they encountered doesn¡¯t fit nicely in the template structure but know that they¡¯re correct, and/or that information which the maintainers need can¡¯t be added in the correct section.
column14: It would be useful to be able to automatically collect information tied to the applications that are at issue. For example, look at the way the reportbug package in Debian allows maintainers to gather additional details about the reporter¡¯s computers and installation that may be critical to understanding the issue.

column12: I have never actually used this Github feature as a maintainer. When I have encountered them as a bug reporter they usually get in my way and make the project seem officious and not actually interested in listening to bug reports. If I used templates myself it would only be to solicit version and configuration information.
